trans-unit.source: Installing .NET Core on Windows
trans-unit.target: Installing .NET Core on Windows

trans-unit.source: By Zlatko Knezevic
trans-unit.target: By Zlatko Knezevic

trans-unit.source: This document will lead you through acquiring the .NET Core DNX SDK via the <linkText>.NET Version Manager (DNVM)</linkText><title></title> and running a "Hello World" demo on Windows.
trans-unit.target: This document will lead you through acquiring the .NET Core DNX SDK via the <linkText>.NET Version Manager (DNVM)</linkText><title></title> and running a "Hello World" demo on Windows.

trans-unit.source: .NET Core NuGet packages and the .NET Core DNX SDKs are available on the <linkText>ASP.NET 'vnext' myget feed</linkText><title></title>, which you can more easily view on <linkText>gallery</linkText><title></title> for the feed.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core NuGet packages and the .NET Core DNX SDKs are available on the <linkText>ASP.NET 'vnext' myget feed</linkText><title></title>, which you can more easily view on <linkText>gallery</linkText><title></title> for the feed.

trans-unit.source: Installing DNVM
trans-unit.target: Installing DNVM

trans-unit.source: You need DNVM as a starting point.
trans-unit.target: You need DNVM as a starting point.

trans-unit.source: DNVM enables you to acquire one or multiple .NET Execution Environments (DNX).
trans-unit.target: DNVM enables you to acquire one or multiple .NET Execution Environments (DNX).

trans-unit.source: DNVM is simply a script, which doesn't depend on .NET.
trans-unit.target: DNVM is simply a script, which doesn't depend on .NET.

trans-unit.source: You can install it via a PowerShell command from a command prompt window.
trans-unit.target: You can install it via a PowerShell command from a command prompt window.

trans-unit.source: You can find alternate DNVM install instructions at the <linkText>ASP.NET Home repo</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can find alternate DNVM install instructions at the <linkText>ASP.NET Home repo</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The script will set several global environment variables to make using DNVM easier in the future.
trans-unit.target: The script will set several global environment variables to make using DNVM easier in the future.

trans-unit.source: In order for these to kick in, you need to restart your command shell session.
trans-unit.target: In order for these to kick in, you need to restart your command shell session.

trans-unit.source: Installing a .NET Core DNX
trans-unit.target: Installing a .NET Core DNX

trans-unit.source: It's easy to install the latest .NET Core-based DNX, using the dnvm install command.
trans-unit.target: It's easy to install the latest .NET Core-based DNX, using the dnvm install command.

trans-unit.source: This will install the 32-bit version of .NET Core.
trans-unit.target: This will install the 32-bit version of .NET Core.

trans-unit.source: If you want the 64-bit version, you can specify processor architecture.
trans-unit.target: If you want the 64-bit version, you can specify processor architecture.

trans-unit.source: You can see the currently installed DNX versions with dnvm list.
trans-unit.target: You can see the currently installed DNX versions with dnvm list.

trans-unit.source: note
trans-unit.target: note

trans-unit.source: The version numbers above can and will change when you run the commands, which is normal.
trans-unit.target: The version numbers above can and will change when you run the commands, which is normal.

trans-unit.source: Don't forget to use the proper numbers when further interacting with DNVM in the below samples.
trans-unit.target: Don't forget to use the proper numbers when further interacting with DNVM in the below samples.

trans-unit.source: Using a specific runtime
trans-unit.target: Using a specific runtime

trans-unit.source: You can choose which of the installed DNXs you want to use with dnvm use, specifying arguments that are similar to the ones used when installing a runtime.
trans-unit.target: You can choose which of the installed DNXs you want to use with dnvm use, specifying arguments that are similar to the ones used when installing a runtime.

trans-unit.source: See the asterisk in the listing above?
trans-unit.target: See the asterisk in the listing above?

trans-unit.source: It's purpose is to tell you which runtime is now active.
trans-unit.target: It's purpose is to tell you which runtime is now active.

trans-unit.source: "Active" here means that all of the interaction with your projects and .NET Core will use this runtime.
trans-unit.target: "Active" here means that all of the interaction with your projects and .NET Core will use this runtime.

trans-unit.source: That's it!
trans-unit.target: That's it!

trans-unit.source: You now have the .NET Core runtime installed on your machine and it is time to take it for a spin.
trans-unit.target: You now have the .NET Core runtime installed on your machine and it is time to take it for a spin.

trans-unit.source: Write your App
trans-unit.target: Write your App

trans-unit.source: This being an introduction-level document, it seems fitting to start with a "Hello World" app.
trans-unit.target: This being an introduction-level document, it seems fitting to start with a "Hello World" app.

trans-unit.source: Here's a very simple one you can copy and paste into a CS file in a directory.
trans-unit.target: Here's a very simple one you can copy and paste into a CS file in a directory.

trans-unit.source: A more ambitious example is available on the <linkText>corefxlab repo</linkText><title></title> that will print out a pretty picture based on the argument you provide at runtime.
trans-unit.target: A more ambitious example is available on the <linkText>corefxlab repo</linkText><title></title> that will print out a pretty picture based on the argument you provide at runtime.

trans-unit.source: If you wish to use this example, simply save the <linkText>C\#file</linkText><title></title> to a directory somewhere on your machine.
trans-unit.target: If you wish to use this example, simply save the <linkText>C\#file</linkText><title></title> to a directory somewhere on your machine.

trans-unit.source: The next thing you will need is a project.json file that will outline the dependencies of an app, so you can actually run it.
trans-unit.target: The next thing you will need is a project.json file that will outline the dependencies of an app, so you can actually run it.

trans-unit.source: Use the contents below, it will work for both examples above.
trans-unit.target: Use the contents below, it will work for both examples above.

trans-unit.source: Save this file in a directory next to the CS file that contains your code.
trans-unit.target: Save this file in a directory next to the CS file that contains your code.

trans-unit.source: Run your App
trans-unit.target: Run your App

trans-unit.source: You need to restore packages for your app, based on your project.json, with dnu restore.
trans-unit.target: You need to restore packages for your app, based on your project.json, with dnu restore.

trans-unit.source: You can run your app with the DNX command.
trans-unit.target: You can run your app with the DNX command.

trans-unit.source: This will instruct the currently active DNX to run your app.
trans-unit.target: This will instruct the currently active DNX to run your app.

trans-unit.source: Note that you didn't need to actually build the code; DNX will take care of this for you.
trans-unit.target: Note that you didn't need to actually build the code; DNX will take care of this for you.

trans-unit.source: Building .NET Core from source
trans-unit.target: Building .NET Core from source

trans-unit.source: .NET Core is an open source project that is hosted on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: .NET Core is an open source project that is hosted on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: This means that you can, at any given time, clone the repository and build .NET Core from source.
trans-unit.target: This means that you can, at any given time, clone the repository and build .NET Core from source.

trans-unit.source: This is a more advanced scenario that is usually used when you want to add features to the .NET runtime or the BCL or if you are a contributor to these projects.
trans-unit.target: This is a more advanced scenario that is usually used when you want to add features to the .NET runtime or the BCL or if you are a contributor to these projects.

trans-unit.source: The detailed instruction on how to build .NET Core windows can be found in the <linkText>.NET Core Windows build instructions</linkText><title></title> on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: The detailed instruction on how to build .NET Core windows can be found in the <linkText>.NET Core Windows build instructions</linkText><title></title> on GitHub.
